abstract.p: Dr Michael M Gindi letter on July 18 article holds over-prescription of Prozac is symptom of our times; photo

block.p: Setting aside the latest controversy over Prozac's potential side-effects, it is important to note that many practicing clinicians still consider the over-prescription of Prozac to be as much a symptom of our times as it is a cure for our symptoms.

Setting aside the latest controversy over Prozac's potential side-effects, it is important to note that many practicing clinicians still consider the over-prescription of Prozac to be as much a symptom of our times as it is a cure for our symptoms.

In an era when the courts routinely reward personal irresponsibility, when everything from a foam coffee cup to a Champagne cork must sport a warning label alerting us to the obvious, we ought not be surprised when many physicians indiscriminately prescribe a passive feel-good drug instead of encouraging patients to actively look at their lives.

Recently, a patient came to me after quitting an H.M.O. psychiatrist who immediately cost-effectively ''Zacked'' him for his depressive tendencies. The patient said: ''I began to realize that maybe I should feel a little sad about continuing to wreck my marriage with a series of illicit affairs. On Prozac, I was starting to feel just fine about it.''
DR. MICHAEL M. GINDI New York
